title: 113_hr2760
content: The Act may be cited as the "Panama Canal and Pan-Pacific Exhibition Centennial Celebration Act". The Panama Canal, built between 1890 and 1914, was a significant engineering feat led by President Theodore Roosevelt. It connected the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, saving sailors a dangerous 8,000-mile journey. The 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco commemorated the completion of the Panama Canal and the 400th anniversary of the discovery of the Pacific Ocean. The event featured the issuance of five different coins by the United States Mint, including the first coins to bear the motto "In God We Trust". The Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco in 1915 featured the issuance of five different coins by the United States Mint, including a silver Panama-Pacific half dollar and four gold coins in various denominations. The largest coin authorized by Congress was a unique $50 octagonal gold piece, marking the centennial of the event and the opening of the Panama Canal. Proceeds from the sale of these commemorative coins supported educational programs of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 octagonal and round gold coins, as well as two and one-half dollar gold coins, with specific weight, shape, and composition requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue $5 octagonal and round gold coins, as well as two and one-half dollar gold coins, $1 gold coins, and half dollar silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition requirements. The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender. Coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act should closely resemble the five coins issued by the San Francisco Mint at the Pan-Pacific Exposition, including $5 octagonal and round gold coins depicting the goddess Minerva on the obverse. The coins minted under this Act should closely resemble those issued at the Pan-Pacific Exposition, including an owl perched on a pine bough with pine cones and needles on the reverse, and inscriptions of "PANAMA-PACIFIC EXPOSITION" and "SAN FRANCISCO" on the rim. The octagonal coin will also have an obverse and reverse design. The two and one-half dollar gold coins minted under this Act will feature an obverse design of the Greek goddess Columbia riding a hippocampus seahorse with a caduceus in her hand, and a reverse design of an eagle perched on a plaque inscribed with "E Pluribus Unum" and "United States of America". The $1 gold coin minted under this Act will feature a man wearing a cap symbolizing a laborer who worked on the Panama Canal on the obverse, and two dolphins representing the meeting of two oceans on the reverse, with inscriptions "PANAMA PACIFIC EXPOSITION" and "SAN FRANCISCO". The half dollar silver coins will also have a unique design. The silver coins minted under this Act will closely resemble the 1915 Panama Pacific Exposition half dollar coin. The obverse will depict Columbia scattering flowers towards a sunset on the Golden Gate, designed by Charles Barber. The reverse will show an eagle on the union shield with an oak branch for stability and an olive branch for peace, credited to George T. Morgan. The coins minted under this Act will have inscriptions of the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Secretary may issue circulating clad half dollar coins in the same design as half dollar silver coins. The issuance is limited to 5 consecutive years starting in 2017, with no more than half of the total coins issued each year being from this section. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2017. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount on sale prices. Sale prices for prepaid orders will be discounted at a reasonable rate. SEC. 8. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act, excluding specific coins, will have surcharges ranging from $10 to $35 per coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for exhibitions and the adaptive reuse of the Old Mint. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit organizations receiving funds for exhibitions at the Palace of Fine Arts. There is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs that can be issued in a calendar year. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to carry out the provisions of this Act.
